Last month the Pilgrim Baptist Church in Chicago burned to the ground while undergoing renovation. This church was described by various news accounts as being the home of modern American gospel music. 
 
 Recently the governor of Illinois, Rod Blagojevich, pledged one million dollars to help rebuild the church. This seems like a gross violation of church/state separation, yet he claims in an article in the Chicago Tribune:
 
 
 "...that Pilgrim Baptist was a historical landmark in the African-American community, serving as a haven for blacks during migrations from the South. In addition, in the 1950s, and especially in the 1960s, this unique historic church was a place of tremendous activity and an anchor in the civil rights movement..." 
 
 
 It may be worth noting the governor is facing re-election this year.
 
 Question: Is the appeal to a historic site a red herring? Should taxpayer dollars be used--in this church or any other church--to rebuild what will essentially be a private organization for use by its members?
Jo Bennett

It depends. Is the church a tourist attraction or widely used as a community centre as well as a place of worship? If either is true then there is some grounds for public funding, just as there would be for cleaning, say, Stonehenge even though it is a place of worship for some pagans.

I'm with Jo. If what you (and the governor) say about the church is true, than I think it is a worthy thing for the governor to support in rebuilding, church or not.

I misspoke. The governor has pledged the money to rebuild the church's school and admin offices, which were also damaged in the fire. This is the fine line Blagojevich is walking to avoid the obvious problem. It was so subtle that I missed it the first time I read it. But in pledging money for those expenditures, isn't he in effect freeing the congregation of its rightful duty to shoulder the expense of rebuilding? Money is fungible.
 
 I don't believe as a public citizen that I could partake in their services and share communion for instance. I would have to become a member first. At least, this is how other Baptist denominations are set up.
 
 I think this is a blatant ploy for the black vote in the gubernatorial election, and he should not be allowed to spend public dollars on a private concern. His trick to not earmark monies for the sanctuary itself should fool no one.

 Your assertion that it's a ploy may be true, but I don't see that as relevant. Would you care if he was rebuilding a black school, or a building that played largely in black history that wasn't a church? I'm guessing no, it's the fact that it's a church that concerns you. 
 
 Under what circumstances can the government skirt seperation of church and state? One of them is when there is a compelling government interest. It seems to me that getting a school rebuilt, as well as a historical landmark, could qualify. It really depends on the details. Is the school open to all? Is it really a historically significant building? Based on the info you've supplied I'd say the Governor is more guilty of buying votes than violating seperation of church and state.

It's the church's school, sectarian in nature, so it's open to Baptist schoolchildren only. The administrative office which was destroyed naturally supported both school and sanctuary. I object on those grounds--using public money to fill kids' minds with church dogma.
 
 Regarding the historical aspect, if it is indeed such a magnificent site that we're all at a loss I would suspect private donations from across the city, state, and country would be forthcoming. Government money could be better spent on clearly secular needs.
